abstracts.cdata!:
The overall project outcome was
            satisfactory: the goals of reducing the state s role in the
            economy, improving the solvency and efficiency of financial
            intermediation, and strengthening banking supervision were
            satisfactorily met. On the other hand, the restructuring of
            the new Guyana National Cooperative Bank was unsatisfactory;
            and the goal of enhancing the business environment was
            adjudged marginally unsatisfactory. Both World Bank and
            Borrower performances were satisfactory overall. The
            following are the main lessons learned: Inter-agency
            arrangements both financial and institutional and, in
            particular, the absence of documentation delayed the
            privatization process. Wide disparity in the value of the
            same asset base made it difficult for the Privatization Unit
            to arrive at the true value of enterprise assets. Although
            worker participation was a key objective, the financial
            status of many workers and the large asset base of most
            enterprises made this difficult. The investment agency
            (GO-INVEST) has not been as effective as expected due to
            several changes in the leadership, thereby delaying capacity
            building. When the financial situation of the newly merged
            Guyana National Cooperative Bank (GNCB) deteriorated, the
            government decided to contract a new management team, which
            has been able to stem further losses of the bank's portfolio.
